subject: RE: [junit] testXXXX must return void?
msgSnippet: ... Yes, but if I were you I wouldn’t just trust what some stranger like me on the Internet told you. If you really want to know the answer, look at the
messageBody:
> From: areider [mailto:areider@...]

> Is it true that test methods must return void in order to be
> considered a test method?

Yes, but if I were you I wouldn’t just trust what some stranger like me
on the Internet told you. If you really want to know the answer, look at
the source or trace through test execution with a debugger. There's not
very much code there so it wouldn't take more than 30 minutes to have
intimate knowledge of the whole thing.

> It seems that if a value is returned from a
> testXXXXX method, it is not included.

Yes.

> Is there a hard reason why? (ie would it break junit to allow test
> methods which return values

One reason not to do that is that supporting (utility, etc.) methods
might be interpreted as test methods. You'd have to make sure they never
start with 'test'.

> or is it just a convention to make the
> introspection easier?)

Probably. The originators might have thought of some other reason as
well.

>
> I would like to write test methods that I can reuse outside of junit,
> where I would want to inspect the result of the test. Right now I'm
> faced with writing the methods twice.

Write those methods as you'd like to and then just 'publish' them for
JUnit's consumption with JUnit style test methods that just wrapper/call
them.
